data.title: 9 hearty summer salads from Twin Cities' restaurants
data.meta_description: The perfect dinner salad has protein, a variety of vegetables, some sort of crispy component — nuts, croutons or bacon work well — and a tasty dressing, preferably not of the bottled variety.
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

It’s officially summer, and it’s officially hot.

That means that not only am I seldom interested in heating up my kitchen or standing in front of a stove, but also that when I do go out to eat, I am often interested in a cold, refreshing dinner.

Salads are the easiest way to accomplish that, but I’m also often dissatisfied with restaurant versions when I’m looking to make a meal of one.

My perfect dinner salad has protein, a variety of vegetables, some sort of crispy component — nuts, croutons or bacon work well — and a tasty dressing, preferably not of the bottled variety.

I ate a LOT of salads for this story, and there were many that didn’t make my list. But here are nine that I’d eat all summer long.

Who makes your favorite dinner salad? Let me know what I missed at eat@pioneerpress.com.

Thai & Stop Me from Crisp & Green

All the good bits were buried in this salad — but trust me when I say there were radishes, orange wedges, cabbage, basil, mint and carrots. It somes with shrimp, but I was feeling chicken, so switched it. The peanut butter dressing is just like your favorite peanut butter sauce — salty, sweet and satisfying. The best part about Crisp & Green’s extensive salad and bowl selection? It’s about as fast as going through a drive through.

Multiple metro locations, including 975 Grand Ave. or 2111 Ford Parkway in St. Paul; crispandgreen.com

Agra Harvest Salad at Agra Culture

This salad is one that’s actually so filling you don’t need to add protein, but a well-cooked piece of salmon was a welcome addition. Chock full of beets, cauliflower, kale, cabbage, cranberries, sunflower seeds and candied walnuts, the ingredient list reads like a health-food checklist. Oh, and it’s delicious to boot. I like to order ahead online so my salad (and smoothie, they make great ones) is ready when I arrive.

Four metro locations, including 721 Cleveland Ave., St. Paul; 651-788-7009; agra-culture.com

Roasted Beet and Goat Cheese Salad at The Copperfield

So often when we’ve been faced with a busy evening of kids’ activities lately, the answer to what’s for dinner is neighborhood gem The Copperfield, which is close to my kids’ school. And what I want in a restaurant in my hood is not only a juicy burger (they have) but also a crisp, green salad. This roasted beet salad is a classic combo — sweet, earthy beets and tangy goat cheese are made for each other — and if you add freshly grilled chicken, it’s filling enough that you’re not tempted by the fries on your dining companion’s plate.

735 Maple St., Mendota Heights; 651-240-6759; thecopperfieldmn.com

Farmhouse Salad at Churchill Street

This simple, well-executed and ultra-fresh salad might just be the most memorable one I tried for this story. Really great greens are at the heart of it, but springy asparagus, roasted beets, juicy chicken, a super light buttermilk dressing and enough parmesan cheese to coat the plate like a fresh snowfall all combine for a satisfying, virtuous meal.

4606 Churchill St., Shoreview; 612-466-2596; churchillst.com

Nicoise Salad at French Meadow Bakery & Cafe

I love a good Nicoise, and this one — loaded with bright greens, hearty roasted potatoes, vibrant green beans, salty olives and sweet tomatoes — is a winner. The perfectly cooked salmon on top makes it a really satisfying meal.

1662 Grand Ave., St. Paul; 651-789-8870; frenchmeadowcafe.com

Shrimp Eggroll Bun Salad at Ngon Bistro

Any bun salad is usually a good bun salad, but the super crisp shrimp eggroll version here is probably my favorite in town. Tender rice noodles, mixed greens, lightly pickled carrots, cucumbers, sprouts and a typical Vietnamese vinaigrette finish things off. If you haven’t been to Ngon’s patio, it’s a quaint little gem with an outdoor bar, pergola, chandeliers and lots of greenery. The craft cocktails here are creative and delicious, too.

799 W. University Ave., St. Paul; 651-222-3301; ngonbistro.com

Farmer Steak Salad at Ingredients Cafe in White Bear Lake

This gigantic salad is served on a platter-sized plate and is one of the most filling of the bunch I’ve listed here. A hefty portion of tender hanger steak is accompanied by greens, quinoa, beets, goat cheese, carrots and candied walnuts, and a house-made walnut vinaigrette really wakes the whole thing up. I love the fact that they often have live music for ambiance, too.

4725 N. U.S. 61, White Bear Lake; 651-426-6611; ingredientscafe.com

Kurdish Salad at Babani’s

Layers of rice, warm lentils, crisp iceberg, tomatoes and cucumbers are accompanied by juicy chicken here for a salad I’m happy to eat any time of the year. It’s probably the salad I crave the most, to be honest. It’s also accompanied by a slice of the restaurant’s fabulous bread, and if you order it for dinner, a cup of soup — I recommend the tangy, lovely lemon dowjic.

32 E. Fillmore St., St. Paul; 651-602-9964; babanis.com

Cobb Salad at Foodsmith

A well-made cobb salad is always a treat, and Foodsmith’s version does not disappoint. Fresh greens, plenty of blue cheese, crisp bacon, juicy tomatoes, zippy radishes, edamame and a perfectly cooked hard-boiled egg made me a happy diner. And the boozy version of an Arnold Palmer that’s currently on the cocktail menu was a great accompaniment on a recent 100-degree day.

973 S. Smith Ave., West St. Paul; 651-330-0896; foodsmithpub.com

Originally Published: June 30, 2022 at 5:00 a.m.
